div.p: who when they came to the Pipe-bearers stopt short – when the Rattle Snake, succeeded by Monsr Gissom, with a humble step & downcast eyes went up to them & offered the & held them the pipe which each Chawyen seemed to have drawn three whiffs – then claping their hand on their breast, which was as much as to say that it did my heart good[.] In this manner they served every one we meet with, till the Chief arrived with about 200 horse-men in his suite[.] The Chief was mounted on a milk-white horse, & dressed in his war dress, harranguing the Shawyens as he was coming along – his followers passed on our right hand & came up behing us – when the Chief cryed out to us to make a General hault – then came down from his horse & embraced the Rattle Snake, then stripping himself as naked as his was the day he came to the world he clothed the Rt Snake with his flashy war dress & with the assistance of others mounted him on his white horse[.] This being done the Chief lead the horse by the Tether barefooted & barebodyed to the Camp* which was 3 good miles off, & the pipe which he received in his right hand the end of the stem pointed to the Camp & himself sang or lamenting all the way, in a language that which none of us could understand, if there were any thing in it to be understood[.] But Monsr Gissom followed them without the least notice being taken of him[]. All the others as well as myself followed behind[.] I drew the attention of the curious, & was surrounded by many, both old & young who treated me with great seeming Kindness[.] At last we got sight of the Camp which was pitched on an Elevated spot on the L. bank of a beautiful River[.] The Leather Tents were pitched in a circle which circumferenced the space of six acres[.] The exact number of Tents

*Some nations have the custom of carrying the Ambassadour of a neighbouring nation into their Camps on their Shoulders but most frequent on a Blanket or a fathom of Cloth; but if none, on a Buffalo Robe between four Men.
